text:
I recently started using ant 1.5.1, and it seems like ant is causing my windows 
explorer to crash. Several other services crashes or stops working at the same 
time and a reboot is required to continue work.

I see no fixed pattern as to when explorer crashes, but it typically does 5 - 
10 times per day.

At first I thought that it couldn't be ant that caused this behaviour, but some 
observations make me quite sure that it is related to ant.

1) I've never seen this behaviour before I installed ant
2) After a reboot, it never happens before I start compiling programs
3) It also happens on my home computer (Also Win2k)

It often happens when I use window explorer (expand a catalog, move the window, 
etc), but sometimes it happens without me touching explorer.

My system properties tells me that I have Windows 2000 5.00.2195
My ant -v tells me that my ant is built on Oct 2, 2002
If it has any relevance my java version is j2sdk1.4.1_01
creator: kp@seacrown.net

text:

unlikely, yet you say you can replicate it across machines. Can you post your
build file, so we can see if there is something special about it. Also, are you
using clearcase?

text:
There is nothing in here that is particularly unique or unusual, so no obvious
cause springs out. One possibility is simply the clean target; that used to lock
up my clearcase filing system, and even bulk dir deletion can confuse explorer
as things it thought existed disappeared. But we'd have heard by now if that was
common; we do hear often of times when <delete> fails because explorer is
holding on to a dir and wont let it be deleted. 

Because there are no obvious problems, I see no obvious solutions. One cause may
just be memory consumption...track in taskman what the memory consumption is,
and maybe the shell keels over when there isnt enough. If you were getting
bluescreens in a build I'd certainly suggest a bad DRAM block, but the explorer
on its own is less clear cut. 

Maybe you could try using jikes as your compiler, instead of the sun one. At the
very least, it will be faster, but it also has a different memory pattern.

-steve
